review.title: Efficient Task Collaboration with Execution Uncertainty
review.abstract: We study a general task allocation problem, involving multiple agents that collaboratively accomplish tasks and where agents may fail to successfully complete the tasks assigned to them (known as execution uncertainty). The goal is to choose an allocation that maximises social welfare while taking their execution uncertainty into account. We show that this can be achieved by using the post-execution verification (PEV)-based mechanism if and only if agents' valuations satisfy a multilinearity condition. We then consider a more complex setting where an agent's execution uncertainty is not completely predictable by the agent alone but aggregated from all agents' private opinions (known as trust). We show that PEV-based mechanism with trust is still truthfully implementable if and only if the trust aggregation is multilinear.

sections.heading: When Agents are Not Risk-Neutral
sections.text: We have shown that once agents are risk-neutral in their execution uncertainty, PEV-based mechanisms are sufficient to incentivise agents to reveal their true types. However, in many real-world applications, participants are often not risk-neutral. For example, when we book a ride from a taxi / car-sharing company to catch a flight, we certainly do not want to take any risks to get an unreliable booking. On the other hand, we often face difficult tasks that are very unlikely to be completed successfully (e.g. open research questions and financial investment), but we are very willing to take risks to try it. Our results suggest that we need better solutions to deal with these non-risk-neutral environments. In addition, if agents are not risk-neutral, individual rationality needs to be redefined (definition 2), as the current definition assumes that agents are risk-neutral in their execution uncertainty.

sections.heading: Challenge of the Efficient Allocation Design
sections.text: In our model, we assumed that the possible results of the task assignment are given and that the efficient task assignment is selected from this set. It is worth noting that when a specific task assignment is assigned, it cannot be so easy to find an efficient assignment (Ramchurn et al. 2009; Stein et al. 2011; Feige and Tennenholtz 2011; Conitzer and Vidali 2014). If it is mathematically difficult to achieve an efficient result, there are techniques to solve this problem without violating the truth properties (Nisan and Ronen 2007). Conclusions We examined a general task assignment problem where multiple agents perform a number of tasks together, but they cannot successfully complete the tasks assigned to them. In order to design an efficient task assignment mechanism for this problem, we demonstrated that a verification mechanism based on execution is truthfully implementable, and only if all risks are unrelated to their performance.
